titlePart.supplied: Call for a Moratorium on Babies

sourceDesc.bibl: 2-Year Holiday on Babies Urged by Mrs. Sanger, New York Herald Tribune, Sept. 18, 1931, 17.

headNote.p: Sanger made a statement to the New York press. No other versions found.

docBody.head: 2-Year Holiday on Babies Urged By Mrs. Sanger

div.head: Birth Control Leader Calls for a Moratorium Until Unemployment is Past. For Rich and Poor Alike. Says Better Uses Can be Found for Money Now.
div.p: A moratorium on birth -- "No more babies for two years" -- was proposed yesterday by Mrs. Margaret Sanger, leader of the birth control movement as one means of meeting the economic crisis. Facing a winter of unemployment, parents should not bring more children into the world, to complicate their own economic problems and burden further the charitable institutions, she said.

p.q: Returning from a vacation in the Adirondacks Mrs. Sanger found that the Birth Control Clinical Research Bureau, 17 West Sixteenth Street, had received an unusually large number of patients since September 1, of whom at least one-third were women whose husbands were out of work.

div.p: “No woman should have any more children this year or until the industrial situation has returned to normal,” said the advocate of birth limitation. “Every child that is born now will only add to the financial distress of the family, imperiling the health of the older children and adding a presumably ill-nourished and puny specimen of humanity to a world that is already overburdened with dependents.

“This moratorium should apply not only to the very poor, but also to the well-to-do. This is a period of anxiety for the rich as well as the poor--perhaps of greater anxiety for them, as they are not so accustomed to financial insecurity. The poor have always a narrow margin between security and peril. They can endure the nervous strain of today better than some of those who actually have more money. Even in a well-to-do family a child would be better off not to be norn just now, while the mother is anxious and nervous. I am perfectly sure that a nervous mother’s condition is reflected in the child. There is no doubt about it.

“Moreover,” she said, “if a family has money there are better uses for it just now than in bringing more children into the world. It would be better to keep alive those we already have than to complicate the social structure by adding more.”

p.q: Asked if a moratorium on births would not add to unemployment by depriving doctors, nurses and manufacturers of infants’ wear of their normal livelihood, Mrs. Sanger replied that they could find other sources of income better than a family could find ways of supporting a child of unemployment.

div.p: In order to meet the increased demand for birth control information in the industrial crisis, Mrs. Sanger’s committee have decided to add a third period to the hours when the clinic on West Sixteenth Street is open for business.
